user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarDelete:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarDelete(osal_id_t var_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CondVarDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarDelete:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR 0x0D
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in the supplied function modifies the function parameter var_id. var_id is a scalar (osal_id_t typedef to uint32) and is only passed by value to OS_ObjectIdGetById, so it cannot be altered by that call per C language call-by-value semantics. The function only assigns to local variables (token and return_code) and passes the address of the local token to other routines (OS_CondVarDelete_Impl and OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete). Passing &token may allow those callees to modify the object referred to by token, but that is allowed by Rule 17.8 (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). There are no assignments to var_id, no taking of its address, and no pointer parameters that alias var_id in this function, so no fragments need investigation for Rule 17.8.
